abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Human Capital Protection
            Project for Colombia were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: Careful, country-specific
            design is key to the success of a social assistance program.
            Project preparation headed by a strong local team and early
            involvement of the executing agency were key factors in
            program success. Being able to show concrete results on the
            ground is critical to maintaining the legitimacy and
            sustainability of the program. Coordination with other
            donors limits the demands put on clients. Involvement of the
            private sector in the implementation of the program improved
            efficiency and transparency. The program provides incentives
            for local governments to make services available for the
            poorest. However, relying on municipal governments in the
            implementation of the program also presents challenges. The
            Bank should not overestimate (i) its ability to respond to
            crises in a country where there is no social safety net in
            place; (ii) the length of time it takes to design a new CCT
            program; and (iii) the amount of time needed to design and
            contract an impact evaluation study. Regarding points (i)
            and (ii), setting up a new program requires time and careful
            examination by competent administrators and lawyers.

5087437.trustfund:
TF026299-PHRD-HUMAN CAPITAL PROTECTION
            (CASH TRANSFERS) AND SOCIAL SECTOR ADJUST
5087437.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Human Capital Protection Project
            aims to alleviate the impact of Colombia's current
            economic crisis on the most vulnerable by protecting and
            promoting poor children's human capital. This will be
            accomplished by supporting poor families' investments
            in their 0-17 year old children's health, nutrition,
            and education in the face of sharply reduced incomes. The
            project consists of six components: 1) The Educational Grant
            Component will finance scholarships for children aged 7-17
            years old belonging to families with SISBEN (Beneficiary
            Selection System for Social Programs) 1 classification. 2)
            The Health/Nutrition Grant Component will finance direct
            cash grants to eligible families with 0-6 year old children,
            who are not in the community nutrition and pre-school
            program of the Colombian Institute of Family Welfare (ICBF).
            3) The Project Management Component will finance the
            operational activities of the temporary National
            Coordinating Unit. 4) The Monitoring and Evaluation
            Component will finance the external review and evaluation of
            the performance and impact of the project. 5) The Promotion
            and Dissemination Component will support public relation and
            information campaign activities via mass media. 6) The
            Health, Education, and Nutrition Services Delivery Component
            consists of education, health, and nutrition services
            provided by involved public institutions to eligible project
            beneficiaries in the participating municipalities receiving
            Bank-financed grants.
